quiz.title: Unit 9: Market Failure & Public Policy (Quiz 3)
quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Income Distribution, Lorenz Curve, Gini Coefficient
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Income Inequality, Poverty, Lorenz Curve, Gini Coefficient, Transfer Payments

questions.question: The Lorenz curve is a graphical representation of
options: the relationship between inflation and unemployment
the distribution of income or wealth in an economy
the production possibilities of two goods
market supply and demand for labor
questions.explanation: The Lorenz curve plots the cumulative percentage of total income earned by cumulative percentages of the population, showing income distribution.

questions.question: If a Lorenz curve moves farther away from the line of perfect equality, this indicates
options: income inequality has decreased
income inequality has increased
average income has risen
the poverty rate has fallen
questions.explanation: The line of perfect equality is a 45‑degree line. The farther the Lorenz curve bows away from it, the greater the income inequality.

questions.question: The Gini coefficient is calculated as
options: area between the Lorenz curve and the line of perfect equality / total area below the line of perfect equality
area below the Lorenz curve / total area below the line of perfect equality
difference between the richest and poorest quintiles’ income shares
ratio of the top 10%’s income to the bottom 10%’s income
questions.explanation: Gini coefficient = Area between Lorenz curve and 45‑degree line (A) divided by total area under 45‑degree line (A + B). It ranges from 0 (perfect equality) to 1 (perfect inequality).

questions.question: A Gini coefficient of 0.40 suggests
options: perfect income equality
moderate income inequality
extreme income inequality
negative income distribution
questions.explanation: Gini coefficient ranges: 0 = perfect equality, 1 = perfect inequality. A value of 0.40 indicates moderate inequality (typical for many developed countries).

questions.question: Which of the following government policies is most directly aimed at reducing income inequality?
options: Tariffs on imported goods
Progressive income taxes and transfer payments
Subsidies for agricultural exports
Deregulation of industries
questions.explanation: Progressive taxes (higher rates on higher incomes) and transfer payments (e.g., welfare, unemployment benefits) redistribute income and reduce inequality.

questions.question: The poverty line is typically defined as
options: the average income of the bottom 20% of households
an absolute income level below which a family is considered poor
the income level of the median household
the point where the Lorenz curve intersects the 45‑degree line
questions.explanation: The poverty line is an absolute threshold (often based on the cost of a minimal standard of living) below which individuals or families are classified as in poverty.

questions.question: Which of the following would most likely reduce measured income inequality?
options: An increase in inheritance taxes on large estates
A shift from progressive to regressive taxation
A decrease in the minimum wage
A reduction in need‑based college scholarships
questions.explanation: Higher inheritance taxes on large estates reduce the intergenerational transfer of wealth, which can lessen wealth and income inequality over time.

questions.question: If the bottom 20% of households earn 5% of total income and the top 20% earn 45%, the Lorenz curve will
options: be a straight 45‑degree line
bow significantly away from the line of perfect equality
lie above the line of perfect equality
be horizontal
questions.explanation: When the bottom quintile earns a small share (5%) and the top quintile earns a large share (45%), income is concentrated at the top, causing the Lorenz curve to bow away from the 45‑degree line.

questions.question: A universal basic income (UBI) is a policy that would
options: provide cash payments to all citizens regardless of income
subsidize wages for low‑income workers only
increase taxes on capital gains
offer free public college to low‑income families
questions.explanation: UBI provides a fixed, unconditional cash transfer to every individual, often proposed to reduce poverty and inequality.

questions.question: Which of the following is a limitation of using the Gini coefficient to compare inequality across countries?
options: It does not account for differences in cost of living or purchasing power.
It cannot be calculated if the Lorenz curve is unknown.
It always overstates inequality in developed nations.
It measures wealth but not income inequality.
questions.explanation: The Gini coefficient is based on nominal income or consumption, not adjusted for cost‑of‑living differences. It also does not capture non‑monetary benefits, wealth distribution, or social mobility.

scoreMessages.90: Mastery of Lorenz curve, Gini coefficient, poverty measurement, and redistributive policies.
scoreMessages.70: Solid grasp; review interpreting Lorenz curves, calculating Gini, and evaluating equality‑focused policies.
scoreMessages.50: Needs practice linking Lorenz curve shape to inequality, understanding Gini calculation, and identifying redistributive tools.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on Lorenz curve (plots cumulative income vs. population), Gini coefficient (area ratio), and policies like progressive taxes/transfers that reduce inequality.
